discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the one

Guidelines and Limitations

When you upgrade or downgrade the EPLDs, observe the following guidelines and limitations:

 You can upgrade each module only when it is online. The EPLD upgrade is only disruptive to the module being upgraded.
 If you interrupt an EPLD upgrade or downgrade, the module must be upgraded again.
 In Cisco MDS 9000 Director Switches, EPLD upgrade or downgrade can only be executed from the active supervisor module. To upgrade the supervisor EPLDs nondisruptively, upgrade the standby supervisor and then switchover. After the new standby supervisor is online its EPLDs can be upgraded.
 In Cisco MDS 9000 Series Fabric Switches, be sure to specify 1 as the module number. The switch must be power cycled for the EPLDs to start running the new code.

Answer B is correct.
The EPLD upgrade is only disruptive to the module being upgraded. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/mds9000/sw/8_x/release_notes/epld/epld_rn_8x.html

questions.question_text: Which statement describes the rolling EPLD upgrade on a Cisco MDS 9000 Series Switch?

choices.A: The standby supervisor module is capable of performing the upgrade.
choices.B: Only the modules that are being upgraded are disrupted.
choices.C: All modules on the switch are disrupted.

questions.answer_description:
Starting with Cisco NX-OS Release 5.2(1), multiple linecards can be simultaneously upgraded, and the infrastructure support is available. This decreases the
ISSU time when compared with an ISSU upgrade that is done serially (one card at a time).
To start a parallel upgrade, use the following command: install all kickstart image system image parallel.
Reference:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus7000/sw/upgrade/guide/ cisco_nexus7000_software_upgrade_and_downgrade_guide_8x.html

discussion.content:
B
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/sw/7_x/nx-os/upgrade/guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_7000_Series_NX-OS_Software_Upgrade_and_Downgrade_Guide_Release_7-x.html#d54e307a1635

Selected Answer: B
b is correct

B is correct 
Multiple linecards can be simultaneously upgraded, and the infrastructure support is available. This decreases the ISSU time when compared with an ISSU upgrade that is done serially (one card at a time).

To start a parallel upgrade, use the following command: 
install all kickstart image system image parallel
As GeekT correctly answer.

questions.question_text: Which command reduces the amount of time it takes to complete the ISSU on a Cisco Nexus 7000 Series Switch that has dual supervisor modules and two I/O modules?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5600/sw/system_management/7x/b_5600_System_Mgmt_Config_7x/m_6k_configuring_span.html#con_1167251

Selected Answer: BC
For the Cisco Nexus 5000 Series Switch, the essential characteristics to consider for the given scenario are:

The types of interfaces that can be used as SPAN source ports (Ethernet, FC, vFC, port channel, SAN port channel).

The requirement that a SPAN source port cannot be a destination SPAN port to prevent conflicts and ensure proper traffic capture.

These considerations make options B and C more universally applicable and critical for configuring SPAN on Cisco Nexus 5000 Series switches.

Selected Answer: BC
B & C are correct

Selected Answer: AC
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus9000/sw/93x/system-management/b-cisco-nexus-9000-series-nx-os-system-management-configuration-guide-93x/b-cisco-nexus-9000-series-nx-os-system-management-configuration-guide-93x_chapter_011011.html

comments.content: While it's true that SPAN source ports can be monitored in multiple SPAN sessions on many Cisco platforms, it is not always possible on all platforms or configurations. Some switches, like the Nexus 5000 series, may have limitations on how many SPAN sessions a single source port can be part of, especially depending on the hardware and software version.

Exactly. Link above is for 9K. SPAN config guide for 5K specifically says "cannot be monitored in multiple sessions" and question reads "Nexus 5000"
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5000/sw/configuration/guide/cli/CLIConfigurationGuide/Span.html

discussion.content: Answer is AC

Selected Answer: BC
Answer is BC

questions.question_text:
The engineer must configure SPAN on a Cisco Nexus 5000 Series Switch to get a capture of the traffic from these applications for an in-depth packet analysis.
Which two SPAN characteristics must be considered? (Choose two.)

choices.B: The Ethernet, FC, vFC, port channel, SAN port channel can be used as SPAN source ports.
choices.D: Only Ethernet, FC, vFC, port channel port types can be used as SPAN source ports.
choices.A: SPAN source ports can be monitored in multiple SPAN sessions.
choices.E: The rx/tx option is available for VLAN or VSAN SPAN sessions.
choices.C: A SPAN source port cannot be a destination SPAN port.

choices.D: If an upgrade is interrupted, the upgrade continues after a connection is restored.
choices.C: The upgrade is performed on the active supervisor.
choices.A: The upgrade is performed from the standby supervisor module.
choices.B: The upgrade process disrupts only the module that is being upgraded.
choices.E: Modules must be online to be upgraded.

as stated by Designated on the MDS the EPLD upgrade affected only the modules being upgraded and the module needs to be online

Guidelines and Limitations

When you upgrade or downgrade the EPLDs, observe the following guidelines and limitations:

 You can upgrade each module only when it is online. The EPLD upgrade is only disruptive to the module being upgraded.
 If you interrupt an EPLD upgrade or downgrade, the module must be upgraded again.
 In Cisco MDS 9000 Director Switches, EPLD upgrade or downgrade can only be executed from the active supervisor module. To upgrade the supervisor EPLDs nondisruptively, upgrade the standby supervisor and then switchover. After the new standby supervisor is online its EPLDs can be upgraded.
 In Cisco MDS 9000 Series Fabric Switches, be sure to specify 1 as the module number. The switch must be power cycled for the EPLDs to start running the new code.

B and E are correct, A is wrong (reference DCCOR CHapter 10 p503):
Update the EPLD on the standby supervisor module. From the active supervi-
sor module, so you must perform the upgrade from the active and not the standby supervisor

B&E.
You can upgrade each module only when it is online.
In Cisco MDS 9000 Director Switches, EPLD upgrade or downgrade can only be executed from the active supervisor module.

AB should correct according to this. 

"On a Cisco Nexus 9500 platform switch that has two supervisor modules, upgrade the EPLDs for the standby supervisor and then switch the active supervisor to the standby mode to upgrade its EPLDs. The supervisor switchover is not disruptive to traffic on Cisco Nexus 9500 platform switches. On a switch that has only one supervisor module, you can upgrade the active supervisor, but this will disrupt its operations during the upgrade."

Under Installation guidelines. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus9000/sw/92x/epld-rn/nxos_n9K_epldRN_924.html

questions.question_text: Which two statements describe the process of upgrading an EPLD on a Cisco MDS 9000 Series Switch? (Choose two.)

choices.B: EPLD upgrades are capable to be completed without powering down the module during the upgrade.
choices.C: An upgrade verification identifies the impact of each EPLD upgrade.
choices.D: The EPLDs for all the modules on a switch must be upgraded at the same time.
choices.E: EPLDs are capable to be upgraded without replacing the hardware.
choices.A: EPLDs are only capable to be upgraded to the latest EPLD image.
